channel.title: Brain dead
channel.description:
We were debating this issue in school a while ago, and an interesting discussion came about. Wikipedia definition:
Brain death is a legal indicator of death in the USA that refers to the irreversible end of all brain activity (including involuntary activity necessary to sustain life) due to total necrosis of the cerebral neurons following loss of blood flow and oxygenation. Brain-stem death (not whole brain death) is taken to be the significant indicator of death. The significant point is that the brain is no longer capable of sustaining the rest of the body's systems without advanced life support. It should not be confused with a persistent vegetative state. The concept of brain death emerged in the 1960s, as the ability to resuscitate individuals and mechanically keep the heart and lungs functioning became prevalent.
In other words, a perfectly functioning body with perfectly functioning organs with a seemingly unresponsive brain (determined after only a couple of hours...). I personally believe it's a bullshit excuse to discontinue life support and harvest the organs while they're fresh. There have been countless cases of people who have been declared "brain-dead", yet awake from their coma (or whatever other vegetative state) with functional brain response after a short period of time. Here are a few of many, many stories indicating this: http://www.startribune.com/local/east/15545747.html http://www.theinsider.com/news/751481__Brain_Dead_Man_Wakes_Up_Goes_on_Today_Show http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-404832/Brain-damaged-patients-wake-following-sleeping-pill-treatment.html http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/2006/sep/12/health.healthandwellbeing etc. In class, people mentioned that there have been cases of women declared "brain-dead" giving birth while in that state. If they're dead, how the hell is that possible? Also, in order to remove all organs from the body, the procedure is preceded by anesthetic treatment - if the brain is dead, and the nerves of the body are dead, why is it that we sedate the so-called dead patients before performing this procedure? What do you think? ps. Don't turn this into another religion thread as this is a medical/scientific debate.

@dragonfire455 wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:34, topic:341211”][quote author=dragonfire455 link=topic=437604.msg3225654#msg3225654 date=1275542886]

Brain dead just means that your brain doesn’t function anymore. It’s the same with kidney failure, which pretty much could mean that you are “kidney dead”. The brain is an organ, the heart is a muscle. You can jumpstart a heart because it’s a muscle, and when your heart functions, so do most of your other organs.

What I’m trying to say is that “brain dead” simply means brain failure, and it’s only lethal because you can’t transplant a brain. Once the brain stops functioning, it will slowly decay. Live support can keep other functioning organs alive, but it won’t bring back “you”. So it’s better for your relatives to terminate.

PS: I’m not a medically trained either.
[/quote]If you’re brain dead then your body can’t function at all. So if they’re technically dead, why put them on life support?

Because technically they aren’t dead. They are put on life support, and after that relatives don’t want to pull the plug.[/quote]They can’t feel anything if they’re brain dead. They aren’t even conscious. And if they are, I’d imagine ending their life to be a whole lot more merciful than to make them continue to exist in that state.

item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:27, topic:341211”]i don’t see why there has to be a single rule for issues like this. there should be a set of guidelines, and it should be decided whether someone is officially dead on a case-by-case basis.

as yakman said, nobody can precisely define life and the same goes for death. it’s the cerebrum which gives us high level thinking, and makes us and other animals seem intelligent. if the brain is dead and the rest of the body is somehow functioning, we don’t have high level thinking - therefore we don’t feel pain or any of the other factors associated with living (from the patients point of view).

we only stay alive because the spinal cord and other nervous systems are unaffected, but these can only perform basic tasks based on strict ‘rules’. if you view simple input/process/output as life, then you could say a computer is living because it can respond to inputs in the same logical way.[/quote]

You can’t do it on a case by case basis, that’s stupid. Or rather, it IS done on a case by case basis, and what we are discussing is the guidelines.

When you said “its the cerebrum that gives us high level thinking” etc., you seem to be implying that with a cerebrum and no brain stem we can live? We can’t. You don’t survive without a brain stem.
